div.p: As it is Performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON, Printed for W. JOHNSTON in Ludgate-street; J. DODSLEY in Pall-Mall; and T. DAVIES in Russel-street. MDCCLXV.
TO HER GRACE THE DUCHESS OF BEDFORD THIS PIECE IS MOST HUMBLY INSCRIBED, BY HER GRACE'S MUCH OBLIGED, MOST GRATEFUL, AND OBEDIENT SERVANT,

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p:
THE hint of this Piece was taken from one of the Contes Moraux of Marmon
tel, stiled L'Hereux Divorce. The foible ri
diculed in the tale is, perhaps, the only one imputed to our sex which has never yet been exposed by a theatrical representation. It is a simplicity, not a coquetry; it is the error of a delicate and elevated mind, unacquainted with the manners of real life, or the general frame of the human heart.

The novel was too barren of incident to furnish out an entertainment for the stage, which obliged me to contrive an intire un
der-plot, and introduce several new charac
ters into the Comedy, which I shall not take up the reader's time to point out here; and submit this performance to the candor and clemency of the public, after having, per
haps, too adventurously hazarded their criti
cism and censure.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: Enter, at opposite doors, Serjeants POMPOUS and PLACID, pleaders in the court of Parnassus: They look round the house.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: HERE's a full court.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Come, brother, let's begin.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: The judges, are they seated?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Just gone in.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: The jury?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Special; freeholders in wit.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: E comitatû lit'rator'm, the pit.
So far, so well. Come, now let's see the pannel:
No pack'd one for the job, I hope, no canaille.
sp.stage: Placid takes out a paper, and reads.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: The foreman, Silence.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Sense, Spirit, Taste;
And by their fellows you may guess the rest,
Including Mercy, which, tho' last, not least.
Good men and true, all sworn before Apollo,
To hear the truth, and nought but justice follow.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: Know then, my lords, and gentlemen o'th' jury,
We've found a bill i'th' records of old Drury,
In which the culprit's charg'd, in this here cause,
With rankest treason against nature's laws,
By introducing 'mong the scenes of life,
A thing unheard-of, a Platonic Wife;
Fair, blooming, and 'bout twenty-five—no more—
I thought, at least, she had been sixty-four!
Here rests my plea: In order to make good
The rights and properties of flesh and blood,
For evidence upon yourselves I call,
And set the cause on this, to stand or fall,
Have ye now one Platonic Wife among ye all?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: My lords and gentlemen, attend a while,
Nor let too specious words your sense beguile.
My brother's somewhat warm; but, entre nous,
Might not Platonic Wives suit some of you?
Men fond of hunting, drinking, or debate,
Would they repine at a Platonic mate?
Their hearts are aliened from domestic life,
And hounds, or wine, or party, are a wife.
Besides, he argues from the common laws,
But I in equity defend the cause;
Plead, women are not bound by Nature's rules,
Nor are their morals borrow'd from the schools:
How many sacrifice their youthful charms
To an old, wealthy husband's feeble arms!
Or yield to titles what they owe to merit,
Wretched themselves, that children may inherit!
These sure are Platonists, who thus forego
Nature's true joys for wealth, or rank, or shew!
Our heroine, tho' she differs wide from these,
Has but refin'd upon the same disease.
Our auth'ress too, perhaps, to aid her cause,
May boast herself the great sublime she draws.
By reason's standard, then, you judge amiss
Of those whose legislator is caprice:
I therefore crave exception for this night,
And plead the privilege of Female-right.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: Well, Sirs, the case is stated, proofs at hand,
All ready here in court, at your command.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Listen with candor; as she merits, treat her.

sp.speaker: POMPOUS.
sp.l: Freely condemn,

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.l: Or honourably acquit her.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: LUCY, maid to Emilia, Mrs. HIPPISLY.
BETTY, maid to Clarinda, Mrs. LEE.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Drawing-Room. Lady FANSHAW and CLARINDA discovered.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I REJOICE to find that your ladyship's good nature is as much delighted as mine, at lady Frankland's happy escape from the galling chain of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
Why really, Clarinda, I look upon it, that next to the felicity of widowhood is that of being sepa
rated. However, there are, my dear, some mate
rial differences: While the tyrant lives to whom we have been bound, we never can forget we have been slaves. There are, besides, some other dis
agreeable circumstances which attend a separation, from which, thank Heaven, my state is free.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You mean, I suppose, the power a husband has of withdrawing alimony, in case of indiscretion, and forcing the wretched wife upon certain moyens de vivre, whether she will or no.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
True. Now you know that since that Gothic statute of the Black-Ram, in the North-west Rid
ing, has been abolished, we widows may chuse what hobby-horse we please; sometimes, for varie
ty, perhaps an ass; but oh! defend me from a mule, 'tis so vastly like a husband.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
Oh! the happiest simile in the world: for, on my conscience, they seem equally to be deviations from the laws of nature. However, when broke, from restiveness, they are the best pack-saddle am
blers in the world.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: But now, my dear Clarinda, that we have got this pretty little bird out of its cage, what think you will it do with its freedom? 'Tis vastly wild, and will, I imagine, take flight to some Arcadian grove, and sit and sing alone.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
O no; that must not be: it would disgrace our generalship. She dies for sentimental passion; and when once her romance is known, I warrant we shall be able to supply her with pretenders enough, who may assume by turns, the crook and scrip, the helmet and the lance, to hold her in play. Nay, piqued as she was at what she stiled lord Frank
land's indifference toward her, I am persuaded that if one tender tear had but glistened in his eye, at the instant of their separation, she would have sunk into his arms, and like the plaintive turtle, have
moaned and cooed away the remainder of her life, in true conjugal insipidity.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I am surprized this did not happen, for I am quite of opinion that lord Frankland loves her.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: He certainly does; but then he did not deify her. My lord knows himself to be a mere mortal man, and has not the presumption of lxion, to cope with goddesses.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: He once, I think, admired you, Clarinda; it was thought you liked him too: how happened you to escape the noose?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
Platonics, lady Fanshaw, all Platonics. So vul
gar a notion as matrimony, never once, I believe, entered either of our heads; and I dare swear he wishes now, that he had never changed his mind since in that article.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
'Tis possible he may; and that at length, tired with the pettishness of a spoiled child, he may re
turn and throw his devoirs again at the feet of one who will at least treat him like a reasonable creature.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
I dare not indulge the hope; but I shall endea
vour though, to lay every obstacle in the way to their re-union. Lady Frankland is young and handsome; she may be virtuous too; but how long that same fortress, called Chastity, will hold out when besieged by flattery, the love of which is her chief foible, I cannot say.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
Why just as long, Clarinda, as any other fortress, where the governor loves money, and the besiegers come up to his price. But among those who either are, or pretend to be, her adorers, I cannot yet per
ceive that she has shewn the smallest preference; and I really believe that she admires Alexander, Cy
rus, or Orondates, more than any man alive.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Perhaps she may think so too; but be assured, lady Fanshaw, that any person who ardently desires to inspire a romantic passion is not unsusceptible of a natural one; and when that takes place, she will e'en act an old proverb, and accept of the living dog, instead of the dead lion.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: But come, my dear Clarinda, and let us attend the levee of this eccentric comet, which, like other blazing stars, perhaps glitters but to fall.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A dressing-room. Lord FRANKLAND gazing on a female picture.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Thou beauteous shade of that angelic form, whose wild caprices have destroyed my peace, I could for ever gaze upon thee! As lord Townly says, "Why did I marry?" Oh! rather say, Why did I quit my charge, deputed as I was her virtue's guard?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Good morning to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Good morrow, Charles.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I grieve to find your lordship's contemplations still fixed upon that gloomy subject.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: And wherefore should they not? Why gloomy, Charles? Look with what innocence she smiles upon me! and sure that painting is the portrait of her heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have not the least doubt of lady Frankland's innocence or virtue; but surely, my lord, it were a childish folly to cast our play-thing from us, then sit and mourn its loss.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have not done so, Charles: I have thrown a diamond in a flaming furnace; if it escape without a crack or flaw, its value then is proved.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Ay, if it does, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Why should you doubt it, Charles? I know her merits, and her foibles too—her real love of virtue, with her fond wishes to inspire a vain, romantic passion.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
And can you think, my lord, that to obtain so fair, so rich a prize, there are not men who will as
sume the semblance of a more romantic passion, than even your lordship feels?

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Perdition's in that thought! Oh, Charles, had I but shewn the thousandth part of that fond love I feel for lady Frankland, this fatal separation ne'er had happened.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p:
I have been, my lord, to inquire lady Frank
land's health, and was answered by her woman that her ladyship had sat up late, reading a new ro
mance; that she had wept much, and slept little, but was in tolerable health this morning.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: May each new morn, fresh from its downy wings, shed health and happiness around her! Order my chariot, Ambrose, and see that all things are got ready for my departure this morning. I shall go to Belle-veüe, for how long I know not. Perhaps air, exercise, and change of objects, may throw off this sad weight.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Shall I accompany your lordship?

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
No, Charles; you seem to have some doubts of lady Frankland's conduct: I would have you, therefore, be a witness to it; for my part I have none. Your intimacy with Emilia, who now lives with my wife, will furnish you with sufficient op
portunities to know every step she takes, and I shall thank you with true gratitude, to deal with strictest justice.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Ay, toward myself I will. This poor, weak man has parted from his wife, for wishing he should love her, and now sits pining at yon baby-face, and longs to have the limbs to it again. But should that happen, he may perhaps get others, which must contract and cripple mine. Counsellor Frankland, with four hundred pounds a-year, and that dipt up to the chin too, is but a poor lover sor Emilia, with
fifteen hundred; but the same man, heir to lord Frankland's rank and fortune, sounds well enough. Therefore the case stands thus: my bird is almost caught, and shall I loose the string, and let it fly, to lure his to the nest again, where it may sit and breed, while I am whistled down the wind to prey at fortune?

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: An anti-chamber in Lady Frankland's house.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Nicodumpus, Nicodumpus, maka de hot vater for my lady breakfast. Vite, Nicodumpus.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: What can she mean now?

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p:
Why you no stir, Nicodumpus? my lady up this half-an-hour, and has no gota her tea. In my countré de valet de chambre hava de caffé, de ga
teau, ready again de lady sit up in her bed; they carry it to her ruelle, they clap it upon her lap, they tell her de news of de ville, of de compagne, of every ting in de vorld; they maka her laugh, and put her in de bon humeur for de whole day. O, de English serviteurs sont de mere bétes!

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p:
Why there now, youse run on at a fine rate, and Ise does not know what youse been jabbering about, this half hour. The Devil take all your country, say I: Youse come over here, poor, sorry, lean, spectacles, to take the bread out of our English
mouths, and then prate to us in outlandish gibber
ish, of ruelly's, villy's, and Cato's. But I'll be hanged if Mrs. Cato, that lived with my lady be
fore she ever saw your ugly feace, were not worth a ship-load on ye.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: What, you filthy animal, do you stand making a names of me? Spectacle! me no spectacle; me no wear de spectacle on my eyes. Ver fine indeed! I vill make complain of my lady directly; I vill maka her turna you out, you miserable ver de terre, and I vill get de French valet for her, who shall know how to treat mademoiselle de Fontange vid de propre complaisance.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Youse turn me out, youse be hanged first. Sure one Englishman is able to flog a dozen of your wishy-washy soup-meagre munseers, let alone such a flippery, flimsey doll Margery, as you.
sp.stage: [Turning her round, and making faces at her.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, de monster, de barbicon! je dechireray ton visage, vid my nail.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: If youse at that work, have at you. [Spitting in his fist.] Noa, damn it, they say she is a woman, and I don't care to strike her, neither. But hearkee me; send your fine man, your varlet, that is to treat you with compliments, and Ise treat him with as sound a rib-roasting, as ever our noble generals gave his countrymen at Minden; ay, that I will.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p:
Goodlack, what is the matter, dear mademoi
selle? you seem to be in a most piteous taking. For goodness sake, Nicodemus, what have you done to poor mademoiselle?

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Why, nothing at all, Mrs. Lucy, and Ise sorry for it: Those damned furbeloes and flounces about her heels there, have saved her beacon, or I'd have trimmed her jacket for her; ay, that I would.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh! he has mada de baddest names of me—he calla me de spectacle, de marjoram—oh, oh!

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Dear mademoiselle, do not take on so, though it is very affecting really. Come, Mr. Nicodemus, pray ask mademoiselle's pardon; come, kiss and be friends, do now.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Ise ask her pardon! Ise kiss her! not I truly—Isc just as soon hug an hedgehog. Let her be glad she was not a mon, and go off quietly with what she has gotten.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Come, dear mademoiselle, walk in with me; your nerves seem mightily affected, and I have got some excellent hartshorn, which I hope will compose you.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, de béte, de monster!

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Discovers Lady FRANKLAND at her toilet, reading.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.

q.l: Where thought meets thought, ere from the lips they part,
And each warm wish springs mutual from the heart,
This sure is bliss, if bliss on earth there be—

sp.p: Heigh ho! why cannot I repeat the rest? Dear unhappy Eloise; but oh! far more unhappy lady Frankland! She had experienced those transports she so feelingly describes, whilst I, unhappy I, with all the tenderness of fond affections glowing in my breast, was doomed to the embraces of a marble statue! Surely my glass deceives me, or I might well inspire that ardent love which lifts us to the skies upon its seraph's wings. Cruel parents, was it for you I wedded! you chose, indeed, a man of worth and honour for me: O, the rare gift! but to become once weary of a faultless person, is to be doomed to lassitude for life. This surely, is severe!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Upon my word, lady Frankland, you will spoil those fine eyes of yours, with constant poring; and then, I fear you will become so very, very wise too, that our beaux won't be able to converse with you, and we shall absolutely be deserted by every crea
ture, but the grave Sir William Belville, who I be
lieve reads a little, and the sagacious counsellor Frankland, learned in the laws.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I assure you, Emilia, I almost wish I had never learned my letters; sor the delicate and refined sen
timents, which books have inspired me with, have only served to disgust me with almost all mankind.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
And yet you would have me read and sigh, and weep over a parcel of doleful devils, who, ten to one, never existed, nor is it a farthing matter whe
ther they did or no. Not I truly; if knowledge is to make me unhappy, I am sure 'tis wisdom to remain in ignorance; and I heartily wish dame Eve had thought so too.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Yet you lose vast pleasure, Emilia.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Grant it; you must allow that I escape much pain: And I am persuaded, that your ladyship might have been as happy with lord Frankland, as any woman in England, if your ideas had not been perverted and disturbed by an heap of vile roman
tic trash.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: No, Emilia, it was impossible. But let me not accuse my lord for this; my ill stars only were to blame.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Bless me, what had stars to do in that case?—unless you mean stars and garters; and I dare say his lordship might easily have obtained a red ribbon, at least, if that could have rendered you happy.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
My dear wild girl, you have wandered very far from my meaning. When I accused my fate, in order to excuse my lord, it was for not having af
forded me some glorious opportunity of manifest
ing a passion for him, by some noble, generous deed, which must have extorted his admiration, his gratitude, and love. For, to deal candidly, what right had I to have expected that lord Frankland should be a passionate lover? what sacrifice had I made him? by what heroic devotement had I awakened the sensibility of his soul? where was the merit of having obeyed my parents, and accepted for an husband one, to whom I could possibly have no exception?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Indeed, my dear lady Frankland, you talk strange
ly, and put me in mind of a young lady of my ac
quaintance, deeply versed in romance, who, with a
large fortune, ran away with an ensign; but when they had got clear off, she would not be content unless he returned and suffered her to leap out of a window to him: The experiment was made, and the poor lady discovered, and confined, till a more suitable match could be found out for her.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
With which, I suppose, she was miserable for life. Why should love meddle in matches of con
venience? Oh, ye delights of sensible souls! charms of impassioned hearts! where are ye? alas! in free and independent love alone, in the mutual yield
ing of two fond hearts, which have bestowed them
selves!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Oh, for Heaven's sake, dear lady Frankland, don't run on at this rate! I vow I am frightened lest you should tempt me to throw away myself and fortune, upon some beggar in pursuit of these same transports, which, after all, I do not believe are to be found any where but in the heated imagination of some poet or romance-monger.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I hope that my dear Emilia will experience every happiness which she can wish. I own your reproof is just, and I shall henceforth avoid any discourse that may elevate your notions to such an height, as may perhaps make you feel those bitter pangs of disappointment, which have been my lot.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: My dear lady Frankland, I had not the least idea of your growing serious on the subject: But luckily here comes company to divert it. I have some letters to write, and shall return the moment they are finished.
sp.stage: Enter Lady FANSHAW, CLARINDA, and Sir HARRY WILMOT.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Joy to my dear lady Frankland, joy to the world of love and gaity.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
Joy to the lovers of liberty, that you have reco
vered yours.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I thank ye, ladies, for your congratulations; but as yet I confess I do not see of what great advan
tage this same boasted liberty will be of to me. I have really no pursuits to follow, no inclinations to indulge, that need restraint; and to become one's own mistress, at my age, is, I think, a thing rather to be feared than wished.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why truly, madam, yours is a critical situation. But what is female liberty, after all, but a name? for a fine woman can never enjoy it, but in the mo
ment she renounces it; and it is only worth pre
serving, in order to part with it to good purpose.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I am astonished, Sir Harry, to hear you preach such absurd doctrine: Lady Frankland is very young; her ignorance is therefore pardonable; but give me leave, who have been my own mistress these ten years, to instruct her ladyship in the charms and use of liberty, and I fancy she will find there is something in them more than a name.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Madam, I bow to your superior judgment, and must confess I do not know a more experienced guide, to all the paths of pleasure. You and the gay Clarinda here, would have made notable priest
esses,
were the mysteries of the Bona Dea now in vogue. But, madam, [to lady Frankland] I would not have your ladyship discouraged by what I have said with regard to liberty, for 'tis, doubtless, a most delightful thing to be free.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: True, Sir Harry, provided one knows how to use that freedom; but to run gadding about the world, without meaning or design, is certainly a gross abuse of it.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Absolute prostitution of our greatest blessing—But, in my opinion, there is but one measure for your ladyship to pursue; to chuse a proper con
ductor, and leave the rest to him. A person, en
dowed with your ladyship's beauty, and delicacy of sentiment, must surely have the choice of many.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: There lies the difficulty, Sir Harry. When they who wished my happiness, as ardently as I can do, whose judgment and experience were far superior to mine, have erred, what have I not to fear, even in the choice of a mere sentimental friendship, which is all my situation can admit of?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Your ladyship means, I suppose, in chusing lord Frankland for your husband.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
I swear, for my part, I ever thought it an ill
suited match.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why, he is really a good sort of man, and sen
sible enough too, but unhappily wants taste; not at all cut out for discovering the elegant and re
fined charms of your ladyship's mind. Besides,
really the desire of pleasing an husband, is in gene
ral so very languid, that a fine woman seldom ex
erts her most amiable qualities, toward him. To charm, to conquer, she reserves for other eyes, and other hearts than his.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Indeed, Sir Harry, I should look upon myself as highly culpable, if that had been my case. My ut
most wish was to inspire lord Frankland with the most delicate passion: How I have failed, I know not!

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Oh, the sweet plaintive turtle! Come, come, my dear, lord Frankland is a reasonable creature; he leaves you at liberty.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: And you would be unworthy of such rational treatment, should you squander so great a treasure, in idleness or dissipation.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am not much afraid of falling into either of these extremes, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Was there ever so rude a monster, as that Charles Frankland! I met him in the ante-chamber, and made him as civil a curtesy, as any third cousin could possibly do, and the bear came up to me, whipt me about the neck, and kissed me with the same rustic freedom he used to do at my father's in Wales, when he came circuit with the judges, and dined at our house.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Oh, poor Emilia! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Do settle my tucker, Clarinda.
So, Sir, you have followed me, I see.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: He must be a dull hound, indeed, who could be found at a fault, in so short a course. I am glad to see your ladyship,

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
I find your ladyship so much engaged with the croud which surrounds you, that I shall, for the pre
sent, take my leave; but as I have something of im
portance to communicate to you, I intreat you will allow me the honour of waiting on you this evening, when the company may be seated at cards, and I may have the felicity of entertaining your ladyship apart.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I shall be glad to see you, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I doubt it not

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Well now, my dear giddy Emilia, what is this terrible disaster, which you complain of?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Why, madam, all I know of the matter, is, that my cousin seems offended at my being glad to see her.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Not so neither, Mr. Charles; but you need not drag one's cloaths off, as you used to do. Besides, I am not so great a romp as I was, and had not my hair dressed then. I am sure he has disconcerted it mightily; has not he, lady Fanshaw?

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Not much, my dear.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
This fracas will soon be made up, I imagine. Mr. Frankland, you'll do me the pleasure of your com
pany to dinner. Come, ladies.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I shall attend your ladyship. [Exeunt all but Mr. Frankland.] An assignation so publicly made, I think I never saw: it almost wears the face of in
nocence, from indiscretion. This is a rare place to seek a wife in! I think I had better play Sir Harry's game, and look out for an intrigue. Ay, surely, were it the woman only that I sought: but, in that case, the fortune is as transferable as the lass, and I would not give six-pence for the latter, with
out the former▪

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Lady Frankland's house. Mr. FRANKLAND and EMILIA.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: WELL, Mr. Frankland, now that you have drawn me from the company, prithee what is this mighty important business, you said you had to communicate to me?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How can my dear Emilia be so cold—ask such a cruel question!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
I declare I am not in the least cold; I think the weather rather warm for the season: and as to cru
elty, 'tis a most unjust charge, for I vow I never hurt any thing in my life, no not a fly.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How can you trifle thus?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Nay, but it is you that trifle, and I beg you will not detain me, for I am sure the company within will sit down to loo in five minutes, and I would not lose my place at the table, for any considera
tion; therefore, if you have any thing to say, speak, vite, vite, as Fontange says.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Since I find, madam, that you cannot with pa
tience spare a few minutes to one, whose every hour of life is devoted to you, I shall not trespass on you longer, but leave you, madam, to more agreeable avocations.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: No, I swear you shall not make a fool of me, neither; I am sure lady Frankland will ask what business you had with me, therefore do, pray do, tell it me, directly.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
If my eyes have not already made the too pre
sumptuous declaration, then let my tongue avow it—Emilia, I adore you.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! and is that the mighty secret, la
bouring in your breast?—Why, my good cousin Charles, you ought certainly to be a great wit, for you really have a very bad memory, and seem utterly to forget that you have told me the same story, by night and by day, an hundred times at least, within these three years, and that I have al
ways received this pompous declaration, just as I do at present—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I am extremely unhappy, madam, to find that the most important concern of my life should be
come a matter of ridicule and mirth to you. But though you cannot feel for others, let your own danger awaken your sensibility: You stand at pre
sent on the brink of ruin, and have no other place of safety, that I can see, but these arms, to take re
fuge in.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Then sure my case is desperate, indeed! But what danger, Sir, what ruin, am I threatened with?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: With one of the greatest misfortunes that can possibly befal an innocent young woman—the loss of reputation, madam.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
My character, Sir, is far above the reach of ma
lice, nor has the tongue of slander ever yet pro
nounced my name.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
It will not long be silent then, be assured of it, associated as you now are with persons, whose cha
racters have been so long infamous, that scandal has forgot their names.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
I neither know, nor own such vile acquaintance; but if you would not have me think you worse, far worse, than those you have described, speak out di
rectly; name them to me, Sir, nor like a base as
sassin, attempt to wound those by night, you dare not look upon by day.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: My dear Emilia, you are young, and do not see through the artifices of that vile woman.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: What woman? Sure you dare not hint it!

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Lady Frankland is—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: An angel.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I say, a fallen one.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Oh, thou art one, and of the blackest dye!—She vile, she artful! thou art a monster but to think it. Her mind and person are as pure as mountain-snow, which the sun's beams have never glanced upon.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: This is prodigious fine, very poetical truly. But now, my dear Emilia— [taking her hand].

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Stand off; there's poison in your touch, as in your speech.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Are you then deaf, as well as blind? Were you not present this morning, when she publicly gave an assignation to Sir Harry Wilmot? her bed-cham
ber, I suppose, will be the scene.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Sir, I command you silence; let not your ve
nomed tongue offend my ears, with such base, such vile suggestions.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You bid me speak, and you shall hear me out. Is not the grave Sir William Belville ever sighing at her feet, with twenty coxcombs more, who in their turns shall hope, nor hope in vain.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Leave me, Sir; I desire you'll leave me.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: No, my lovely Emilia, I cannot, will not leave you: I will defend you, even against yourself. I have shewn you the precipice, on which you stand; let me now point out the path to happiness and safety. This vile lady Frankland—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Again, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Can never think of returning back to her hus
band again; and, in failure of lawful issue, you know I am his heir; therefore no despicable match for my Emilia.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Thou art indeed, the most despicable, meanest wretch that lives. So, sir, the source of this pol
luted stream, at length appears: You have traduced
one innocent woman, to entrap another. But know, that were you this moment, what I hope you ne
ver will be, in possession of lord Frankland's wealth and honours, and that Emilia had not a shilling in the world, she would fly you with the same detes
tation and contempt, she does at present. And so, my lord Would-be, adieu.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I fear I have over-shot the mark. I thought to have frightened the little Welch puss, with the cry of scandal opening against her, and that she would have taken cover in my arms. But faith she is a stout one, and worth scampering after, the whole circumference of her estate; and, by fair or foul means, I will yet hunt her down.
Serviteur, mademoiselle.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p:
Oh, your honour's tres humble servante; com
ment se porte Mr. Padrick, your honour's Iris ser
viteur? he never a come to see us since a we leave Parliamentary-street. Oh, he be de inconstant varlet!

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I shall take care to chide him for it, mademoi
selle, and send him to wait upon you directly.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p:
Oh, your honour maka me very, very glad. I do like Mr. Padrick dearly, he be so very coxco
mical he maka me laugh; and then he maka de plays vid de kisses in it. Oh, it was very, very sweet.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Well, mademoiselle, Patrick shall certainly re
fresh your lips, with some of those sweet kisses
again. But tell me, how do you like your manner of living, since your removal to Pall-Mall? I sup
pose you are quite happy here without a master.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Oh, point de tout, not at all. My lady she keep a de very bad hour; pauvre Fontange she must sit up for her lady. I am sure me look a de vizard, for want of de sleep.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How happens that, mademoiselle? what can she find to do alone?

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p:
Why she have a de companie dat stay with her sometime till one or two o'clok; den she go up to her chambre; dere she sit down to sigh, or to read a de great big boke; den may be, that laughing miss Emilie she come in, whip away de boke, and sit prate-a-prate to her till we no want candle to go to bed. But I beg a your honour's pardon: I have a de lettre to my lady, from Sir Harry Wil
mot.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Serviteur, mademoiselle. Proceed in your vo
cation.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Your tres humble.—Pray souvenez monsieur Padrick.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
A letter from Sir Harry! What then, his sto
mach does not serve, or perhaps he thinks the treat will keep cold. I am sorry for it. I wish he, or the Devil had her. I know not what to think of her. I greatly fear she may be honest. But if I can contrive any method to ruin her in lord Frank
land's opinion, 'tis quite equal, and she may then remain as chaste as she pleases, for me. This French
woman may be of use: She certainly knows her lady's secrets; and it will be very extraordinary, if an Englishman's gold, and an Irishman's kisses, may not be able to open the lock of that curious repo
sitory. She may assist in my design on Emilia too, whom I am determined to have, were it only to gratify my pique.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A drawing-room in Lady Frankland's house.
Lady FRANKLAND, Lady FANSHAW, CLARINDA, and Sir WILLIAM BELVILLE, seated at a card-table.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
The pool is out, and my cards are really so dis
agreeable that I am tired of playing. I wish Emi
lia would come and take them.
Will you play, Emilia?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: No, madam, I would rather be excused, at present.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then we have done, if your ladyship pleases, and I am glad of it; for I confess I think that play, among friends, is a most shameful misemployment of time, and that cards appear properly in the hands of sharpers only, merely as implements of their trade.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
For all that, Sir William, cards are a very com
fortable resource sometimes.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Ay, where the company is not large enough to make up a country-dance.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
I am sure half the people of fashion in England, would pass many a dull evening, nay, perhaps some of them might hang or drown themselves, if it was not for the relief which these little innocent paint
ings afford.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am so far of Sir William Belville's opinion, that I think avarice is the true source of play; and how persons of liberal minds, and easy fortunes, can reconcile so mean a motive to themselves, is to me surprizing.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
There are few people, madam, who are truly ac
quainted with the springs of their own actions, and many who are actuated by the basest, would be shocked if they knew them.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: This is a grave subject, Sir William; I think we grow rather too wise.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Why I really think so too, so I'll e'en go trifle. O Clarinda, such a capuchin as I saw in the Park, yesterday! I will have just such another positively, and will instantly go enter into close consultation with my milliner, on this important subject.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I wish Sir Harry Wilmot was here; he would enliven us all, even without cards.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
You'll not have your wish to-night, lady Fan
shaw—Sir Harry is engaged.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Prithee where, Clarinda?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
At lady Subtle's: He is solely devoted to her, for the present. Her husband is in the country,
and I dare say he would not spend this evening from her, for a nabob's fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Ridiculous! how can you talk so? why he has been in her good graces, above this month, which is long enough, believe me, to surfeit him. He has had a dozen amours, at least, within these twelve months.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: A dozen, did you say, lady Fanshaw?

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I did indeed; and your ladyship may be assured I have spoken within bounds.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I dare say so too; and yet he has behaved with honour, to them all.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How you amaze me! with honour said you? I thought till now, that constancy in love had been a virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I have met with some such musty moral, among the metaphysics of old romances; but the bon ton of later times, have exploded it long since, I assure your ladyship.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: I humbly beg a mille pardon of your ladyship, and of all de ladyships, for me entre here; but I have a beg of Nicodumpus this half-hour, to bring a this lettre to your ladyship; but he pretend a he do not entendez moi, and I am forced to bring it myself, for which I beg a mille pardon again.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Give it to me, mademoiselle.—I shall return im
mediately.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Each word, each glance, discovers some new charm, And dead, not cold, is he she cannot warm.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
O fye, Sir William! what a mere whining ina
morato you are! why don't you say all these fine things to her face? what signifies your sighing them out, after she has got beyond ear-shot?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: The delicate and high respect I bear toward her ladyship's unhappy situation, must seal my lips in everlasting silence; nor shall I ever breathe a sigh or wish, that may offend her.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW and CLARINDA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: And so you think she would be offended! Lord, Sir William, though you are very young, you need not pretend to be quite so innocent. Offended! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I am pleased to hear you so merry, ladies. Pri
thee communicate the occasion; for I should be glad to try if there be sympathy in mirth, as well as contagion in sorrow. Do tell me what you laugh at.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Lady Fanshaw and Clarinda, madam, were say
ing—

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: What, pray?

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Why, that of all simple animals, a bashful lover was the most ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I believe there are few men, now-a-days, ridicu
lous on that account. I have, indeed, read of lovers who have sighed whole years away, without daring to acquaint the happy object with their passion.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: While, perhaps, the pining fair one sat sighing, in her turn, to waving woods and purling streams, for him again. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
That too might have happened, I believe, Cla
rinda.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
And don't your ladyship think they were a cou
ple of mighty silly mortals?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
You know my sentiments upon that subject, al
ready, ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: For my part, I think there is happiness sufficient, in the bare loving of an amiable object.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: What, without any hope or desire of a return?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
It is impossible to divest a lover of the fond hope of being pitied, at least, by the object he adores; and while he confines his wishes within that bound, he is indeed a lover: but when he vainly thinks his services should merit a reward, perhaps incon
sistent with the honour or happiness of the beloved object, self-love assumes the place of passion, and it no longer deserves even the name.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Upon my word, Sir William, I am charmed with the elegant and just description you have given of
love, and am rejoiced to find the dear idea still ex
ists in any breast besides my own.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
They must be insensible, indeed, who could have had the happiness of conversing with your ladyship, without being, in some degree, inspired by that de
licacy and refinement, which accompany all your words and actions; and if I have been able to con
ceive, or express proper sentiments of the noblest passion, I own myself indebted for them, to my knowledge of lady Frankland.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: This goes on swimmingly; let us leave them together; I dare say they wish us gone, Clarinda.— [To Lady Frankland.] We must bid your ladyship good evening: Clarinda and I are under an engagement to meet lady Rattle, and some other company at Vauxhall.
sp.stage: [Sir William bows to Lady Frankland at the same time, as taking leave.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You are not coming with us, Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: No, madam, but I think it time also to retire. I wish your ladyship good-night.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Stupid fellow! I would not have gone away these two hours, if I had thought so.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Sir William Belville is really a very agreeable and polite man. Oh, if lord Frankland had been capa
ble of his refined, his delicate sentiments of love, how happy had I been! this were indeed the golden age again restored to me!—But let me see once more, what says the gay Sir Harry?
sp.stage:
[Takes out a let
ter and reads.]
sp.p: "Madam,

"I am totally in despair at losing the most pre
cious moments of my life; but company have broke in upon me, and prevented my laying my devoirs at your feet. What would I not give to escape from them! but, unluckily, they are persons of the first condition:—I cannot therefore taste of hap
piness, till to-morrow. I most earnestly conjure dear lady Frankland, to abridge some hours of cruel and distracting absence, by permitting me to attend her levee at the toilet: 'Till then I have the honour to be
Her ladyship's most passionate adorer,
H. WILMOT."

Vain coxcomb! is this then the important busi
ness he had to communicate to me? But I will see him, to mortify the insolence of his presumption.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pray, what is your ladyship ruminating so very seriously upon?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I have much to think of, Emilia; but I pro
mised you this morning, you may remember, to confine my ideas to my own breast. I fancy you look grave too: what, has Mr. Frankland boister
ously presumed to kiss your hand, or neglected to take up your fan, when you dropt it on purpose for him? or—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
No such matters, I assure your ladyship. Yet he has indeed furnished me with a very copious sub
ject for contemplation. But—

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I claim no right over your secrets, my dear; and from the good opinion I have formed of your cha
racter,
I dare say you may be safely trusted with the keeping of them yourself. But, as I most sin
cerely wish your happiness, I must say, that I think you would have a better chance for it with any other man, than Mr. Frankland: There is a reserve, even in his gayest manners, that seems to squint suspicion.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I am so far of your ladyship's opinion, that I promise you Mr. Frankland shall never have it in his power to render me unhappy. But let us talk no more upon so disagreeable a subject. I have just got the last new song, that your ladyship seemed fond of: will you step into the next room, and hear it with the harpsichord?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: With all my heart.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Mr. Frankland's chambers in the Temple.
Mr. FRANKLAND musing. Enter PATRICK with a letter.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
You have staid a confounded while; but I sup
pose you waited for an answer—Give it to me.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Fait, and if I had done that, myself would not have been here so soon itself; for how could miss Emilia give an answer to a letter she would not read, unless she was a conjuror, or a witch?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Not read my letter!

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p:
Not she indeed; she scorned the motion, though mademoiselle palavered her at the greatest rate, and said she was sure it must be very pretty, when it
would come from the young concealor; but madam Emilia she said she would not pry into the conceal
ment; that is, she would not break the seal, I sup
pose. Augh, she is very witty.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Leave your nonsensical prate, and be gone.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p:
Well, there is your letter for you again, safe and sound; not a bit worse than when you gave it me—O yes, fait, it has got a little clean dirt in my pocket, but that's no great signify, it will serve a poor body well enough still. Shall I carry it to Mrs. Susan Ta
per in Threadneedle-street? may be it would bid her bring home the shirts, if she is able to carry them, with the load your honour has given her already.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Blockhead, give me the letter.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p:
Fait, that's very foolish now. I am sure your ho
nour was a full hour a writing it; and what do you throw it away for?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Leave the room. [Exit Patrick.] The insolence of this proud girl, distracts me. I fear I am on the brink of ruin: my fortune mortgaged for more than it is worth; my honour pawned at play; and, what is worse, my credit sunk with her, who was to have redeemed them all! should she acquaint lord Frank
land with what I have said of his wife, his foolish fondness for her honour may make him cast me off, both from his heart and fortune. Beggary, con
tempt, and infamy, stare in my face. I must find out some means to avoid their frowns, or else es
cape from them by the help of a pistol: but as that is at any time in my power, I'll make one effort more, before I draw the trigger, and deserve death, at least, before I fly to it.

div.head: SCENE I.

q.l: TO climates chear'd by other suns,
In vain the wretched exile runs;
Or tho' he mount the rapid steed,

div.p:
How strongly do I feel the force of this senti
ment in my own breast! I hoped the opening charms of the soft breathing spring, would have removed my languor; I grew sick of the country in a few hours, and I shall probably be tired of London, in as short a space.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: I hope I see your lordship in good health; your sudden return has alarmed me.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I thank you, Ambrose; but I am as well as ever I expect to be!

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p:
My dearest lord, you break my heart to hear you talk so sadly. If your old servant guesses right, your malady is love—Love for the sweetest, best of women, your lordship's wife. Oh! she is all made up of gentleness and generosity! I won
der, indeed I do, how you could have the heart to part with her, indeed I do, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Full well I know her exquisite perfections, Ambrose, and admire them all. But with a heart that lov'd as mine did, how could I bear daily to be reproached with want of tenderness and passion for her! I found it impossible to act up to her romantic notions; and as I could not make her happy, I determined not to make her wretched, tho' 'tis too sure that she has rendered me so.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p:
I am certain, my lord, her gentle heart would break, if she suspected that you grieved for her. She ever has received your poor old servant with the greatest kindness, and made me even sit down before her, when she thought that I looked feeble or fatigued, while she inquired minutely of your lordship's health. Then let me go to her, and tell her what I am sure your lordship thinks, I know she will hear me, indeed she will—Oh! on my knees I beg that I may be the blessed messen
ger of peace, the happy cause of your re-union!

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I command you not to attempt it. [The pride of manhood and of love forbid it: could I have condescended to have whined and sighed before her, we never should have parted; but since that has happened, nothing but a full conviction of the injury she has done my love, shall ever make us meet again. Mean time, I will watch over her, like her guardian angel, and shield her from each wrong, or violence, she brings not on herself. Should that e'er happen, my care is at an end.] [Aside.] Go, Ambrose, and inquire her health, and let Emilia know I should be glad to see her. But for your life, breathe not a syllable of what has past.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p:
I will obey your lordship, tho' 'tis the first se
vere command you ever laid upon me.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You will find me in the library.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Lady Frankland just risen from dressing. Fontange settling the toilet.
Enter Sir HARRY, and exit FONTANGE.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Bright as the sun, and as the morning fair! Eh, ma charmante! what an amazing freshness of com
plexion! what a profusion of lovely hair! upon my soul, lady Frankland, you are vastly hand
some.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am glad to see you in such top spirits, Sir Harry. I suppose them the effect of your last night's party.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Last night—Let me consider, where was I last night? Oh the cursed embarras du monde! which prevented my waiting on your ladyship. I have a vast mind to turn shepherd, and renounce the world at once. Should not you like to be a shep
herdess now?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: O vastly! with such a faithful swain.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Egad, and so I am. Constancy is, I think, my greatest foible, at present.—'Tis apt to wear out a mistress's patience.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Then lady Subtle may boast of her charms, if they have been powerful enough to six the lively, roving, Sir Harry Wilmot.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Lady Subtle! why you know, ma chere, her charms are in the wane, absolutely expiring—We have been old acquaintance, and it would have been cruel in me to have refused her the shadow of an amour, when she is so very near becoming a ghost. I am glad to find she is jealous.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Is she in a bad state of health, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: O, by no means, she is as fat and florid as any woman in England of her age, which I believe is near forty.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Pray where is the danger then, of her becoming a ghost?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Helas, ma chere innocente! don't you meet a thousand ghosts in every public place? Bodies without souls, who have haunted the world so long, that they are worn out of every one's remem
brance, and might glide in and out, without ever being taken notice of, if it were not for the space they occupy. Have you never been jostled by a fat red ghost, in the box lobby of the playhouse,
or at the puppet-show cascade at Vauxhall? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: As they differ in every respect from spirits, I should never have thought of stiling them ghosts, tho', as you have explained it, I own the term is apt enough; yet I fancy that blanks would do still better, as some authors have lately used them, merely to make up bulk, and stuff life's volume.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I vow, madam, your ladyship has an infinity of wit, as well as beauty. But now, prithee, dear lady Frankland, what do you seriously mean to do with them both?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I do not find myself overburthen'd with either of those rare qualities, Sir Harry; but if I should, I must e'en look out for some good-natured person, who will be kind enough to assist me in bearing the load.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Ay, now your ladyship talks reason. Mutual offices are the very bands of society. And among the croud of adorers, who bow before your shrine, have you yet fixed on one whom you think equal to so blest a charge? I may be impertinent—Your ladyship's blushes seem to hint as much.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: No, Sir Harry, a heart like mine has nothing to disguise—If I blushed, it was not shame, but pride, that glowed upon my cheek, from the slight notion you seem to have conceived of me, that among the trifling characters which frequent my drawing room, there could be found one capable of attaching my confidence, or regards.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why, that is vastly severe now, when there are such a number of pretty fellows, who dedicate their services to your ladyship. What pains she takes to shew me she is not engaged?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: It would be the height of vanity in me, to set down their visits to my own account, Sir Harry, while I am blest with a companion in my house, whose mind is free, and person disengag'd, and where each charm that can attract in both, unite in my Emilia.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Faith I have always heard your ladyship reck
oned a little romantic, but never believed it till now. Emilia! why we know her price is matri
mony, to become a property for life, egad. And sure no man of spirit would condescend to such terms, unless with a view to lord Frankland's circumstances, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Sir, you grow insolent.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I vow I did not mean it, and ask a thousand pardons—but surely, madam, with that blaze, that glow of youth and beauty which surrounds you, it is impossible you should think of living disengag'd! Were the Hesperian fruit planted in our streets, it would require ten dragons to secure it. Alas! you have not one.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: In this imminent danger, what think you of my appointing such an excellent guardian as Sir Harry Wilmot? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
You may gibe if you please, madam, but I cer
tainly should be the very thing, if I were not so much engag'd. Lord, what shall I do for means to get free!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Pray do not give yourself the least trouble upon that account, Sir Harry, for tho' I am, as you ob
served, a little romantic, I have not bravery sufficient to turn knight-errant; and I must surpass even the renowned Don Quixote, should I think of encoun
tering the numerous host of rivals which your attachment might enrage.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: No, madam, your ladyship is mistaken, there are not a vast number, who at this time lay claim to my devoirs.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: O but, Sir Harry, my heart is so very tender, that I should be moved to restore you back to the groans of lady Subtle, or the first stalking shade of those numberless ghosts your cruelty has made, that might come to haunt me for you.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
I assure your ladyship you are wrong to make a jest of my behaviour to lady Subtle; there are few men of my rank in life, who have either morals, or politeness, sufficient to pay the least regard to a dying reputation.—Now, madam, it has ever been my principle and practice both, never pub
lickly to abandon a mistress; and when I have been insufferably tired of a lady, I have kept my chamber, and seen no company for three days to
gether, in order to give her the credit of the rup
ture. But you are not to expect such nice morals from the generality of men, I'll assure you, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: How you amaze me! is this, Sir Harry, what you stile morals, principles, politeness! to betray, to expose a wretched woman! surely I am in a dream, I cannot think myself awake.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why truly, madam, I think we are both very near taking a nap; we have wandered from the point strangely; and I ought to beg your lady
ship's pardon, for having made so improper an use of the favour you have indulged me in. Eh donc, ma belle, will you now seriously fix upon the happy man, who is to love and be beloved by you?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You increase my astonishment every syllable you utter.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: She must be very ignorant, to be so subject to wonder.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I am young, perhaps not insensible; but neither my youth nor sensibility shall ever betray me into imprudence. If my affections are to be gained, it must be time, assiduity, reflection, the soft ha
bitudes of friendship and esteem, that must obtain them, even without my choice.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
I admire you vastly, madam, upon my soul I do—but I have not the honour to be of the antient chivalry; nor had I the least notion of your lady
ship's allowing me the happiness of a tête à tête, merely to assist you in composing a romance. Adieu, donc, ma chere princesse, belle heroine, adieu.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Where will my wonder end! Is this the man of gallantry, the irresistable Sir Harry Wilmot! Surely that woman must first be a dupe to her own pas
sions, who could comply with his. Not such the lovers I have read of, who sighed whole years in silence, nor to the world revealed their bitter an
guish, their consuming pain; the whispering woods alone were conscious of their woe, till echo caught the sound, and bore it on her dying voice to the beloved fair.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM BELVILLE.
sp.p:
This charming woman fills up all my thoughts, my every wish is her's, nay my whole soul! What delicacy of sentiment, what elegance of form and manners! Happy—rather say unhappy lord Frank
land, whose sure possession made him contemn a prize, that kings might become rivals for.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Why so grave, Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: You mistake, Sir Harry, I was only thoughtful.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why curse me if ever I could distinguish be
tween thought and gravity, in all my life; and as I look upon reflexion to be a mere dull mechanic sort of business, I have resolved never to think, while I live.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: A most rational resolution, truly!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: But, my dear Sir William, egad I had like to have forgot—you are under the highest obligation to me, this very moment; and I will be thanked, positively I will.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
You need but name it, Sir Harry, and rest as
sured of my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why then, Sir Knight, I have atchieved such a feat in your favour, as you will be transported at—cleared the cover'd way, my boy, and left the de
file open to you, and you alone. But not to ar
rogate too much, I must confess that it was pure want of that noble spirit of perseverance, which you are so amply possessed of, that made me quit the assault; for to say the truth, I am tolerable enough at a skirmish, but devilish bad at a siege.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: You speak in riddle, Sir Harry, pray explain yourself, that I may thank you as I ought.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Well then, my dear Belville, thus the matter stands—We have both of us, you know, sighed for that Delia, that Cassandra, that queen of all ro
mance, lady Frankland.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Sir Harry, lady Frankland has a husband, and—

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Sir William, I know she has, and—they are parted; but suppose they lived together; is it not possible to fall in love with another man's wife?
answer me that, and from your heart, my grave Sir William Belville.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: A passion in that place, must be an hopeless one.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Not at all, I assure you; for if I would but have starved on hope, for a few days, I might have lived on certainty, as long as I lik'd it after. But egad, my constitution is not strong enough to fast through a lent, though I were sure to feast at the carnival.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Sir Harry, I hope still I do not understand you; lady Frankland's character is free from blame.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: And always shall be so, for me, I assure you; but to be plain, Sir William, her ladyship did me the honour of an assignation, this morning, for all that.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: An assignation, Sir Harry!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Ay, positively, a tête à tête.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Go on, Sir! egad I don't know whether I shall or no. I fancy I have mistaken my man, and instead of talking to my old friend, Will. Belville, have stumbled on some country cousin, who, because he is related to her ladyship, thinks it incumbent on his honour, to vindicate her's. Go on, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Distraction! torture! [Aside.] Sir Harry, I was only impatient to know the result of this assig
nation.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
To be short then, her ladyship assumed all the airs of an heroine in romance, talked of constancy, assiduity, friendship, esteem—and modestly gave me to understand, that I must dangle some months, at least, after her, before she could think of re
warding my labour. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: But did she promise to be kind upon these terms, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why, not expresly indeed; but sure, Belville, you and I are too well acquainted with the sex, not to know that a constant attendance for a fort
night, a few warm sighs, some drops of heat dis
tilling from the eyes, with a volley of flattery planted against her ears, would have carried this proud princess captive, and made her fink into my arms.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Sir Harry, notwithstanding the lightness of your manners, I have ever believed you to be a man of honour; I must therefore suppose, that you have framed this story, purely to try my opinion and re
gards for lady Frankland; and that on that disco
very, you will freely own the falsehood.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: The falsehood, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Yes Sir—to traduce that lady's honour, is the basest, meanest falsehood. She grant you an assig
nation!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: By heaven, she did.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: By heaven, 'tis false, and thus I will assert it.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Nay then, have at you, in defence of truth.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: In defence of honour.
sp.stage: Enter CLARINDA at the side of the stage.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Bless me! what's the matter!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Sir William, my life is in your hands.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then take it freely. I hope you are not hurt.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Not much. If you know how to use it, this adventure will be a vast advantage to you. A con
quering lover is a treasure in romance, virtue is her fort, but sentiment her foible. Help me to my chair, 'tis at the park gate, my wound grows painful, and the walks begin to fill. Do not boast of this affair to any one but lady Frankland.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Upon my honour, I shall not, even to her, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Success attend you, you deserve it.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
To deserve is to obtain, Sir Harry; for he who founds his schemes in honour, has already secured
to himself that self-applause which is more pre
cious than any other gratification can possibly be.
sp.stage: [Exeunt. Sir Harry leaning on Sir William.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: "Virtue is her fort, but sentiment her foible." That must be lady Frankland. 'Tis very odd, now, I have coquetted with half a dozen at once, and have been kind to two or three, and yet never had the honour of a duel being sought for me, tho' I have endeavoured to set the men together by the ears, with all my might. But these sly, slow things, that have either the reality, or appearance of virtue, do fifty times more mischief, than we good natur'd, generous hearted girls are capable of doing. Or perhaps our gallants, like our nation, love fighting for fighting sake, without any hopes of being paid for it.
Oh Emilia! such a dreadful accident!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Bless me! what has happened?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: A duel between Sir William Belville, and Sir Harry Wilmot.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: How did it end?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I fear 'tis all over, with poor Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: But Sir William, dear Clarinda, what of him!

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: So, my little sly one, you are caught, I sind—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Can one hear of bloodshed, without concern?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: But why distinguish between the combatants?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pshaw, prithee tell me the whole of this story?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Prithee first tell me, whether your emotion arises from sentiment, or passion?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Neither, neither; compassion all.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
Well then, all I know of the matter is, that just now as I entered the park, I saw these gen
tlemen both draw their swords, and engage; and before I could get up to the place, Sir William had become master of Sir Harry's sword.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Were they both wounded?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I cannot inform you, I know Sir Harry was.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Surely the provocation must have been great that could tempt them to draw in the park. I thought Sir William had more temper and pru
dence. Do you know the subject of this quarrel?

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I know there was a woman in the case, whom I dare pronounce to be lady Frankland.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Impossible! what right have either of them to asperse or vindicate her fame? She neither does, nor can belong to either of them.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
That is perhaps, the very reason why they fought about her. A woman in her circumstances, is looked upon as lawful plunder, to which the long
est sword gives a title.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: My dear unhappy friend, I am grieved to the heart for her. I was going to visit lord Frankland, just across the park, but I shall first return to her for a few minutes. I intreat, Clarinda, that you will not mention this affair to any mortal.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Not I, you may depend upon it. The secret would burst me. [Aside.] But shall I send to know how Sir William does?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pshaw, I hope he is not hurt, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Farewell, Emilia.
sp.stage:
As Emilia is going out, she is met by Mr. Frank
land.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am fortunate, madam, in meeting you in a place, where you cannot avoid me.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: You are much mistaken, Sir, if you think it is not what I would wish to do in every place.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have no reason to doubt your sincerity, madam, but it was carrying your cruelty too far, to refuse reading my letter—No judge condemns unheard.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I have heard you, Sir, and from your own lips condemn you, nor can any of your artful palliatives ever induce me to change my opinion. I therefore request that you will spare yourself and me the fruitless trouble of attempting it; for be assured, that I will never receive letter or message, nor hold converse or commerce with you more.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: For heaven's sake hear me one word, my Emilia!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: No, Sir. But to rid you of perhaps your greatest uneasiness, I promise you I never shall repeat the vile calumny you thought proper to insult me with; so that your secret remains safer, even in a woman's breast, than it was in your own. But for the future, I advise you to be more cautious.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
So then, all is safe with regard to lord Frank
land I find.—But what an ass am I to think my
self so, while I am in the power of a woman? no, that can never be, till she is in mine.
Well Patrick, have you seen Fontange?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Yes, please your honour, I have seen her all over.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: What's all over?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Why by my shoul she is all over impudence, I think.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p:
Why faith, when I enquir'd for her below, they said she was above; so up I went to the top of the house, to the very garret, to her chambray, as she call'd it, and knocked at the door, out of pure civility, she answer'd, enter, or entry, or something like that; so in I went, and found her sowing on her bodices, without so much as an apron or bed
gown about her shoulders—augh, she has made me sick about the heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You are plaguy dainty, truly, to be offended at seeing a woman half naked.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p:
Augh hone, my jewel, if it was one of my own country girls, with a skin as white as a crud, or a new potatoe, it would not have affected my sto
mach that way.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Well, hold your nonsense—did she promise to come to my chambers?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Faith, honey, it is but ask and have with her. I'll be bound she is there already.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: And you, blockhead, have got the keys, run home directly, I'll follow you as quick as possible, fly—

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Troth let her wait, I'll not fly a step for her.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Be gone.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A drawing-room in Lady FRANKLAND's house.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
YOU cannot imagine, my dear Emilia, how much I am shocked at what you have told me. I fear I shall now become a common topic of dis
course. What a triumph for lord Frankland! his character will rise upon the ruin of mine.—Good heaven, what will become of me!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Indeed, my dear lady Frankland, you first de
ceive yourself, and then argue right, upon wrong principles. You must certainly imagine lord Frank
land a monster, before you can suppose it possible for him to rejoice at your dishonour. On the con
trary, I am certain he would be sensible of the highest concern, were he acquainted even with your present distress.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
O! do not say so, Emilia, I can bear his resent
ment better than his pity. I fear I have de
served the one, and am certain I have no claim to the other.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
You judge too hardly of yourself, my dear; but I have strong hopes that this unlucky affair will never reach his, or any other ears. Sir Harry has nothing to boast of; we may therefore depend on his silence; and I have too good an opinion of Sir William Belville, to suppose him capable of ever
mentioning it; and I would not have your ladyship seem to know one word of the matter.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Grant it should remain a secret, Emilia; how painful must my situation be! conscious of the highest obligation, which I must not acknowledge, even to the generous hand that has conferr'd it To a mind open and grateful as mine, this must be torture.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Have a care, lady Frankland, of over-rating the obligation. Sir William knows that your situation cannot admit of a return, and if I am not much deceiv'd with regard to his character, his senti
ments are too generous to expect one.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: By shewing my want of power to repay it, you but enhance the debt.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Sir William Belville, madam.
sp.stage: Lady Frankland looks at Emilia in some confusion.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Your servant, ladies, I scarce expected the plea
sure of finding you at home this fine day, when all the world is abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: That may perhaps be one reason for our staying at home, Sir William. I hate crowds of every kind.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
If half the world could entertain themselves or others, as either of you ladies can, there would
scarce be such a thing as a crowd: select parties and rational conversation, would then become the fashion. But when the mind is vacant of ideas; its activity will seek them from outward objects, which strike upon the senses, yet leave no more impression, than our forms do on a looking glass; while the charms of refined sense, and elegant converse, remain indelible upon the soul.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
For my part, Sir William, I relinquish any share in that very fine compliment, for I confess I have great pleasure in seeing a number of well dressed people together, looking as if they were pleased themselves, and wishing to please others; and I should certainly have been in the park an hour ago, if I had not staid in compliment to her lady
ship.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You render me uneasy, Emilia, pray do not suffer your complaisance for me to trespass on your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Tho' you modestly refuse it, madam, you have still a part in the eulogium; nor is it for want of ideas in yourself, but to inspire them in others, that you need ever wish to appear in public; and who that sees Emilia, must not be captivated with the pleasing one of sprightly innocence?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Ay, but then, Sir William, it leaves no more impression, than our forms do on a looking glass, you know, so I'll even vanish away.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
All forms, however pleasing, are transient, I con
fess; but when animated by a noble mind, they then become such substances as stars are made of.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Then sure my dear Emilia may shine forth the morning's harbinger, for never was there yet a nobler mind join'd to a fairer person.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
The comparison had been more just, madam, had you alluded to our nightly planet, which bor
rows its reflected light from the bright sun, as she from you.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Your compliment is so very high, Sir William, that there is no replying to it. We seem to have got beyond the clouds, and had better beware the fate of Icarus.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: It were falling indeed, madam, to descend to any terrestrial subject, while I have the happiness of contemplating, and conversing with a seraph.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Upon my word, Sir William, your extravagant politeness distresses me; yet I confess my foible, if it is one, in being pleased at being approved and esteemed by a person of your refined senti
ments. I hope too, that it is a pleasure I may in
dulge with innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Transporting sound! my raptures are too strong for expression. Thus give me leave to thank you.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Oh! Sir William! beware of ecstasies! they are, alas, inconsistent with my hapless lot!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Never, madam, shall I aspire to higher bliss, than what I now enjoy.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir William, I have been led too far▪—But still remember, Sir, that I am bound by the strongest ties. They must be preserved inviolate; and if I am really dear to you, you will ever hold them sacred.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Far, far from Belville's heart, be every wish for transient joys, attended by remorse; much sooner would he die, than e'er create a pang in the soft bosom of sair innocence.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Lady Fanshaw, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
I vow you are a most unaccountable creature, lady Frankland, I have waited for you this full hour; and what is worse, I am afraid the auction is begun, and the room so stuff'd, that we shall not be able to see the beautiful pagoda, nor get into the circle among the men; but be jamm'd up in some obscure nook among the canaille, who frequent such places, merely to stare at their bet
ters, and poison the air with the fumes of tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I ask your ladyship many pardons—I utterly forgot to order a card to be sent, to let you know I could not attend you this morning.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
Vastly polite, truly—not go with me! after pre
venting my being there two hours ago, and getting a seat close to the auctioneer! I should have had the very best place, ma'am, Mr. Langford and I are very well acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: By your own account, madam, her ladyship has done you a favour, by preventing you from being squeez'd up in a crowd.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
You are vastly mistaken, Sir, there is nothing more pleasant, and healthful too; and I am cer
tain half the people of fashion in London would die of fevers, if it were not for the benefit of per
spiration, which they can only receive in such places, as they are too delicate to use exercise suf
ficient to procure it any other way.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
This is really, madam, the only rational argu
ment I ever heard urged in favour of a crowd; and I shall henceforth consider myself, or any of my friends in such a situation, as only suffering a painful operation for the benefit of health.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: But now, dear lady Frankland, you have not an idea of what you will lose, if you don't come with me directly; there's my lord Mount Fashion, who has travelled thro' Persia, and the Mogul's country, purely to acquire a knowledge in painting and architecture, makes his first public appearance there this morning; and will decide exactly, with regard to the value of the bronzes, and the antiquity of the china.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Such a virtuoso must be equally an honour and advantage to his country, surely!

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
O but, Sir William, they say he is a mighty pretty fellow too; in short, all the pretty fellows in Town will be there.—Do come, for heaven's sake, lady Frankland! I shall break my heart if I don't
