go, and I can't decently stalk in alone, like one that nobody knows.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Rather than your ladyship should suffer so ex
treme a disappointment, come then, I will accom
pany you.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
Away, away then, quickly my dear, my cha
riot is at the door. Your's Sir William.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Sir William, your servant.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Lord Mount Fashion, and all the pretty fellows in town there! sure that could not be the motive for her going.—Yet she absolutely refused, till they were mentioned; nor once desired me to accom
pany her. This is strange! Oh! she is too dear to my fond heart! I cannot bear that other men should gaze upon her charms; for if they do, they'll love. I'll follow at a distance and observe her, she will attract all eyes, and I may pass unnotic'd.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: So you think, Emilia, that lady Frankland reads too much!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I do indeed, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Were her books well chosen, that could hardly be; but I fear her studies serve rather to augment,
than amend her only foible. But pray, Emilia, who are lady Franlkand's chief intimates? I do not mean the crowds that fill her drawing room, but those who are admitted en famille.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Does your lordship mean men or women?

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Both, Emilia; but more particularly the latter; for I would have you and every woman I regard, more nice in the choice of their female, even than their male acquaintance. Believe me much de
pends upon it.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Lady Fanshaw and Clarinda are, I think, the most intimate of our female friends; Sir Harry Wilmot and Sir William Belville are more fre
quently with us, than any other men.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You surprize me, Emilia! Clarinda intimate with lady Frankland! I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
And why, my lord? Clarinda is sprightly, sen
sible, and chearful.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Beware of that spirit, sense, and gaiety, Emilia, which have not virtue for their base! they are dangerous instruments in dangerous hands! I am shock'd at her intimacy with my wife, which she has compassed since our separation; and if I have yet any influence with lady Frankland, or with you, you will both immediately quit all con
nection there. The rest of the persons you have named, I am unacquainted with, except Sir Wil
liam Belville, who bears the character of a man of honour. Clarinda! lady Frankland! those names ought never to be joined.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
I am very certain, my lord, that lady Frankland would sacrifice any thing on earth to your desire. I will answer for it that she gives up Clarinda di
rectly. I promise your lordship that I shall.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Do not flatter me, Emilia; could she have sacri
fic'd her only foible to my fond love, we had been blest indeed!

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord, if I suspect that foible might have been cured, if proper means had been applied.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Do not speak of it, Emilia; my wounds all bleed afresh. There was no way to cure it, nor could we have lived on any terms, but by indulging it to an excess, which must have rendered us both contemptible. I am impatient till you see my wife; alas! all that remains to me of that endearing name, is that fair shadow [pointing to the picture.] Let her break off all further commerce with Clarinda, if she regards her own honour, or my peace.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Your lordship need not doubt your being obey'd.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I am grieved at thinking what may be the event of this connection. All women who have forfeited their own title to virtue, envy those who possess it; and would wish to sink them to their own base level. I am certain lady Frankland is virtuous, open, and sincere. But alas! what arms are these, to combat the charms of flattery, the attractions of
pleasure, and the snares of seduction! should she sink under them. I surely am to blame, who have exposed her youth and inexperience to a trial, per
haps too hard. But should she pass this more than ordeal fire, unsullied and unhurt, she will be something more than woman; and adoration, late her claim, will then become her due. I'll hope the best.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: What can my master, and that ugly mademoiselle there, be doing in the bed-chamber within, this full half hour together? Sure the devil would not put an ill thing in his head. Faith myself will peep through the key-hole, and try. [Looks in.] No such thing, at all; they are talking very fast tho', and there can't be no great harm sure, in list'ning to their discourse, since it would not be about love. [Claps his ear to the key-hole.] O faith, here they come, and a body may hear something now.
sp.stage: [Retires to the side of the scene.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Upon a my illegible ord, conceleur, I do run a de very great dangere for your service. Madame Emilic she be de heiress you know, and that do make a it de hanging matter for pauvre Fontange. Ah! Morblieu, si je sera pendue! What a disgrace to my family! not one of dem would own a me, if I should be hanged.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Courage, mademoiselle, the hazard is not so great as you imagine, then think of the reward. A thousand pounds! Why that will enable you to return to your own country, with eclat, set up an equigage, and outshine half the women in Lan
guedoc. Why a thousand English pounds, Fon
tange, twenty thousand livres Françoises, is the portion of a marchioness there.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p:
But are you very sure your honour mean a de mar
riage, after you carry her off? or else Fontange vil a have noting to say to it. She would no turn procurateur for any ting in de vorld; but in de honorable way, she serve a her friend, sans doute.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
O, fear me not, mademoiselle.—You have the best security in the world, over me, my own in
terest.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: You must not come a to de house, till it is black dark; you get a ready de parson and de coach; den leave a de rest to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: My life and fortune both depend on the event.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: I wish a your honour de bon success, vid all my heart; but you will not forget pauvre Fontange. I will have a de bond ready for your honour to sign, when you come a to de house.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: With all my heart, mademoiselle. Would I had signed and sealed with Emilia!

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Tout en bon tems—Adieu, Monsieur, adieu.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Myself was never so bothered what to do, in the course of my whole life. To be sure I would be glad my master was married to madam Emilia, because I believe he loves her. But this stealing her away by night has an ugly look with it.—And to have that wicked mademoiselle get a good thousand pound for helping to ruin the innocent creature; augh, that would vex me to the heart. I'll go directly, and consult with my old friend and gossip, Jimmy Kavanagh, that is in a good place here in town, and may be he would tell me what I would do; for I don't much care to betray my poor master, neither.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Sir HARRY WILMOT in a night-gown;

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I vow, Clarinda, this was vastly kind, now, and really more than I deserve; but I declare, you are the very paragon of good-nature.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
Why truly, Sir Harry, I must say, it shews a most dove-like disposition in me, to hazard my re
putation, by visiting a man who has just now endan
gered his life for another lady.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: There you are mistaken, Clarinda; curse me, if I either did, or would fight, for any woman in England—except yourself, ma belle fille.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: O, your servant, Sir—But what could have been your cause of quarrel, then? For Sir William, I think, never plays.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why, that same doughty knight-errant, you have named, took it into his wise head, that be
cause a certain fair lady had never allowed him a tête à tête, she never meant to indulge herself, or any body else, with one; and upon my declaring that she had done me that favour, talked in a high, ridiculous, romantic strain of the lady's honour and character; and seemed to hint as if he suspected me of a falsehood. That you'll allow was not to be endured.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
O, by no means, Sir Harry. However, I have not quite so much pity for you, as I had, as you were paid, I suppose, before-hand. A tête à tête with lady Frankland, was, I think, an over-pay
ment for the slight scratch you have received. But you certainly did ill to boast: I could not have suspected you of so much dishonour, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why now, my dear Clarinda, there's the mis-chief on't. I had nothing to boast of; for this same petite partie ended in a very absurd proposal on her side, for entering into the Platonic system, which I positively refused. Car je n'ai pas le tems. Admired the elegant impracticability of her lady
ship's seraphics, made my bow, and withdrew.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
Very absurd and ridiculous, truly! Equally so, on both sides. I never could have supposed, that a man who knows the world, as well as you have a right to do, could have slipp'd such an opportu
nity, so simply. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Why faith, Clarinda, there is a kind of bashful courage about those modest dames, that is capable of putting the most impudent fellow in the world out of countenance; and tho' I was never in better spirits for an attack, she talked so queerly of friend
ship, esteem, honour, and such stuff, that she left me little to say, and less to do; so I e'en quitted the field, and marched off.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Shame of all cowards, say I; if your double defeat should be known, you will be hooted out of the world both of love and gallantry; and faith, you deserve it.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Point de tout, ma chere fille, no man is wise or brave at all times, and I shall only smile at my late defeat, if I can but triumph here,

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
Pshaw, let me go; it would be scandalous in me to submit to a beaten general—conquest is the road to conquest, both in love and war; and the illustrious name of our victorious leader, has been a legion added to our troops: English women, as well as men, chuse to list under a brave com
mander.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Vastly severe and piquant, truly! but I shall have my reprisals, some other time.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You'll have better luck than you deserve, then. Farewel, poor recreant knight.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Adieu, ma bizarre!

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: The street before Lady Frankland's house.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Love and jealousy are twins, I find, born in the self-same moment. What transports have I felt, what agonies endured, within a few short hours! That angel form which blessed my eyes and ears this morn, e're noon transformed into a mortal object! surrounded by a crowd of coxcombs! By heaven, she freely gave her hand to lord Mount-Fashion, and suffered him to lead her from that vulgar scene of hurry, noise, and nonsense. I'll see if she is returned. [Raps at the door, and enter Nicodemus] Is your lady at home, friend?

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p:
Noa, Sir, I'se wish she were, for servants are all well y'clemmed, and cook says dinner's a-spoil
ing—Madam Emilia's at home tho', if your ho
nour pleases to walk in.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: No, friend, 'tis very well. [Exit Nicodemus, and shuts the door.] And yet I think I will go in, and wait for her.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Soa, Sir, what mun you want now?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I have changed my mind, and will go in to wait for your lady's return.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: You'se welcome. I'se swear you'se a person of quality, for they never know their own minds. (Aside). Do walk in, Sir, pray.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
After the declaration you made this morning; it surprizes me, madam, to find you in this re
tired situation.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
One often says more, Sir William, as well as less, than they think, according to the degree of spirits they happen to be in. I confess myself a rattle, and have vivacity enough to be fond of public places. Yet, I very soon tire of them, and frequently prefer the gaiety of these little objects, which I can create with my pencil, and the enjoy
ment of my own thoughts, to the more glaring shadows which surround me abroad, and no thought at all. 'Tis vastly pleasant to think some
times, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
They are, indeed, truly unhappy who do not find it so. Guilt alone can make reflection pain
ful.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
I must differ with you, Sir William; for I really know many good sort of people, who I am sure
have nothing to reproach themselves with, yet for want of an early habit, dread sitting alone, as much as if they feared spirits, and would run into any kind of company, rather than endure their own.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Charming, sensible, unaffected girl (aside). He must be a happy man, Emilia, who shall share the pleasures of retirement, with a companion lively and rational as you.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
Pray do not make me vain, Sir William; per
haps no body may have it so much in their power as you.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
That declaration ought to make me proud, ma
dam.—But I have been so charmed with your sen
timents upon retirement, that I almost forgot the occasion of my intruding upon yours. Do you know any thing of lady Frankland? Does she dine at home?

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I have not seen her since morning, but I am so well acquainted with her ladyship's regularity and politeness, that I have not the least doubt of her returning to dinner (looking at her watch). Bless me 'tis very late; I have never known her stay so long abroad.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I have some little business to communicate to her ladyship, and shall take the liberty of waiting on her soon after dinner.
sp.stage: [A noise of rapping at a door within.]

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: O, here she comes; and as you say you have business, I shall withdraw; but pray don't detain her long, Sir William, for I am vastly hungry.
sp.stage: [Lady Frankland speaking before she comes in.]

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Will my dear Emilia excuse me this trespass on her patience? But I vow it was not possible for me to get away from lord Mount-Fashion, one moment sooner. (Enters.) Sir William, your servant.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Your's, Madam; I am surprized that his lord
ship could part with you, even now, Madam: I did suppose you had been gone to dine with him at lady Fanshaw's, or some other of his lordship's fond admirers.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I don't understand you, Sir William; I should certainly have dined abroad, if I had happened to have one of my own servants with me, to have sent home to Emilia. I did not expect the fa
vour of your company, Sir, therefore cannot charge myself with any want of politeness toward you.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Want of politenefs, Madam! is that a term to me? whose heart-strings you have strained, and taught to feel more racking agonies, than e'er Damien knew! keep your politeness for your lord Mount-Fashion, Madam; I hoped I had an higher claim.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Are these the sentiments, Sir William, which gave that claim? Where is that nice respect, those soft expressions of friendship and esteem, which pleaded for that claim?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Vanished, Madam! fled in the moment that you gave your hand to that same peregrine lord.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Delusion all! they never yet existed in your breast; self-love alone assumed the form of senti
mental passion, and has imposed on you, but never shall again on me.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Cruel, unkind! vain metaphysical distinction! you know I would sacrifice a thousand lives to please you, detach myself from the whole uni
verse, and give up every thought to you, and you alone! Is this self-love?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: True love requires no sacrifice, but the heart; self love must have its triumphs: suspicion is its constant mate, and the least degree of complaisance shewn to another object, appears a robbery to selfish minds. In short, there can be no slavery equal to that a jealous lover would impose.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I, Madam, I render you a slave! you, Madam, whose empire is so absolutely over me!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Sir William, I shall ever acknowledge the high
est obligations to you; you have drawn me from the verge of a precipice, into which my own im
prudence had like to have plunged me—I awake from an illusion, and can dream no more—Be my friend still, this is the only rank that you can ever hold in my regards.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Heavens, Madam! what crime have I com
mitted, that you should wish my death?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Far from it, Sir William; I wish your happi
ness, so far as it may not be inconsistent with my own; and by depriving you of all right to be jealous, I lay you under the happy necessity of ceasing to be so. I begin to dread the violence of your temper, and what we fear, we cannot love.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I begin to know you, Madam, in my turn; the refinement of a platonic passion, but ill agrees with the slightness of your conduct. Sir Harry Wilmot would have been a more suitable lover, and I was certainly wrong to interfere—

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Stop there, Sir William; I know already how much I am indebted to you, upon that occasion; and shall therefore retire, to save you the confusion of having reproached me with an obligation, which even this behaviour cannot cancel, nor shall I forget.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Distraction! what have I done! upbraided lady Frankland! she is, she must be irrecoverably lost to me! But by what bond could I have hoped to hold her? Platonics, I am now convinced, are all a jest; and her virtue, and my own honour, both forbid all other ties.

q.l: Accursed jealousy! too well you prove
If for themselves alone we sought the fair,
Kindness to others would not cause despair;
But when self-love begins to warp the mind,
We dread a rival in each passing wind.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: MY dearest Emilia, I have now opened my whole soul to you. My mind is a perfect chaos; yet I feel as if a weight had been taken off my breast, by this most fortunate breach with Sir William. Oh, my Emilia, how near have I been to ruin! I am frighted even at the prospect.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: You should contemplate it rather, with that kind of pleasure, with which they view the wreck, who have just escaped the storm, with a proper sense toward providence, and a steady purpose never to run the same risque again.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Humbled as I now am, Emilia, such resolutions are natural, and bare remembrance of the peril I've escaped, must certainly insure my perseverance. But alas, my friend, have I not reason to accuse my fate, for turning those advantages, which are deemed a blessing to my sex, into a curse for me! youth, beauty, innocence, and sensibility, to what have ye reduced me! to become the sport of fop
pery, or victim of jealousy! Is this the world I have been taught to admire? For what illusions have I strayed from real happiness, which I am now convinced is only to be found, in the calm in
dulgence
of rational affections. In the repose, rather than tumult of the soul.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I rejoice to find that the natural good sense of my amiable friend has been only hoodwinked, but not blinded, and that she can so clearly see her errors now

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Yes, wretch that I am! I see them but too late; after I have forfeited the friendship, the confidence, and regards, of the best of men and husbands! thank heaven, though, that I have nothing to re
proach myself with, except imprudence; and yet, Emilia, can I hope that Lord Frankland should take my word for this, or even condescend to listen to my justification? How I detest the writers of romance! Oh, Emilia, 'tis but too easy to swerve from the right path, but difficult indeed to recover it again.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Why difficult? the little deviation you have made, requires no artful clue. There are no bars against you, but those your fears create. Lord Frankland is still the same tender, affectionate husband he has ever been, and gave a proof of it this morning, by requesting you to quit all farther intimacy with Clarinda, whom he seems to think no safe companion for your honour.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Another precipice! an angel's guard has surely hovered over me! O were he to forbid my converse with all the world, with light itself, with every thing but thee, nay, nay, even with thee, Emilia! his will should be obeyed.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
My heart exults at finding yours so sensible of duty. O, Lady Frankland, you have indeed
escaped from many dangers yet unknown. Nor can a wife e'er find a place of safety, but under the protection of that heaven-appointed guard, her husband. Lose not a moment then, but let us fly to your asylum—That generous man, who has ever pitied and bewailed your errors, will open wide his arms to your returning virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Alas, Emilia, a certain native pride, or rather conscious shame, which generous minds alone, are capable of, restrains my steps. I must first endea
vour to be reconciled to myself, before I can even hope for his forgiveness.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p:
Mr Ambrose is come to wait upon your lady
ship.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: In a lucky minute, sure! a thought has just occurred—If blest with success, my dear Emilia shall be the first partaker of my joy. For the present, leave me. [Exit Emilia, expressing by her looks and gesture her joy and wishes.] Desire Mr Ambrose to walk in. [Exit Nicodemus. Now for the last act of expiring romance!

How does my Lord, and yours, good Am
brose?

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: In health, may heaven be praised for it; I have not been so happy as to see your ladyship, for some time past, though I have called here daily, by my lord's command.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am obliged to his lordship, and to you also, Mr Ambrose.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: O madam, would it were within my power to oblige your ladyship, your poor old servant would lay down his life, to shew his duty.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Then, Ambrose, you have it in your power to do me a most essential service.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p:
Your Ladyship has but to command, and I obey. Would to heaven that my lord and you loved your
selves, but as well as I love either of you. I know not which of you was to blame, but I am sure my heart bleeds for you both. How it used to delight me, to see you together. It was a blessed sight! and since your separation, I have seen nothing but affliction in our house.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I take the blame upon myself, good Ambrose, yet I have hopes my fault may be repaired, if you will but implicitly follow my directions.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: Doubtless, madam, I shall obey.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You know that my picture remains still in my lord's house.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: Ay, madam, and my lord knows it too, full well; he shuts himself up with it whole days, gazes on it, talks to it, then sighs enough to break one's heart to hear him—'Tis all his company and consolation, now—I dare not speak. But—

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Your words pierce through my soul! I have not merited this kindness; I thought his heart insensible
and cold, dead to all tenderness for me; but let his generous foftness quicken mine. Ambrose, you must steal that picture for me, and bring it hither this very instant, unseen by mortal eye.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: What, madam! rob my master of his only treasure! Bid me lay down my life, and I'll obey.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Be assured I do not mean to deprive him of it. This evening you shall replace it in my husband's chamber. My sole request is that you will not let him know it has been moved. You can't refuse me, sure!

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p:
Your ladyship is goodness itself, and I can't sup
pose you would put an end to my life, by the grief it would give me to afflict, or offend the best of masters—I will then instantly obey your ladyship's commands—But pray, good lady, remember that it must be restored, this very evening.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You may rely upon my promise, indeed, good Ambrose— [Exit] Ambrose. To hymen's sacred power, though late, an ardent votary I bend—Oh! may he prosper, and assist my purpose!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: An apartment in Lady FANSHAW's house.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
I can't tell you how much I am disappointed at the folly of that coxcomb, Sir Harry—I had great hopes that his spirited assurance might have conquered her timid bashfulness; and a breach once
made in that bastion, the citadel falls of course. I begin to fear she'll conterwork us all, and either keep the fortress in her own hands, or perhaps de
liver it back again to the former governor, in statu quo.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
I can't agree with you, Clarinda, though even Sir Harry has failed. For I dare swear no woman ever parted from her husband, with a design of playing the drude with all the rest of the world. I fancy now, that Sir William will carry the town—not by storm indeed, but by starving the be
sieged into terms of capitulation.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I don't understand your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Why then, in plainer English, Sir William is grown jealous, and will, if possible, prevent any other man from coming near her. By this means, she will find herself prisoner, and may then probably surrender her person, to obtain her liberty, en parole, at least.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: You deal still in tropes, Lady Fanshaw.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
Ay, but you understand me, for all that, Clarinda. You know full well that when a woman puts herself into the power of a man, he becomes a tyrant, she a slave, from that moment; and all the difference I can find, between marriage and gallan
try, is, that one is perpetual, the other temporary, only.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
I care not by what means her ruin is accom
plished, provided it be accomplished. Her fatal marriage with Lord Frankland, blasted all my
hopes, and I cannot bear to think that she should taste the heart-felt joy of her own virtue, while I am de
prived of that, as well as of what I resigned it for.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
Nay, as to that Clarinda, it is no such mighty matter, that one need wish to rob her of it, for we both know with regard to the world, the appearance will answer, as well as the reality. But if you are bent upon her ruin, blast her reputation, my dear—The story you told me of the duel, pro
perly managed, is sufficient to do that effectually.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: That alone shall destroy her fame, should she even preserve her chastity, which you seem to think improbable.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
I have half a score visits to make to morrow morning and I shall take care to whisper this ad
venture in every one of them, with the tenderest professions of pity for her misfortune, and a who could have suspected it? I vow I thought her perfectly innocent, but I am afraid lord Frankland had his reasons—though he had too much pride to publish them,

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
This will do, my dear Lady Fanshaw; for let women value themselves ever so much upon their in
nocence, the loss of character is next to that of virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: O much worse, Clarinda—But I must go and visit that simple Sir Harry, as he is confined; I own I despise him, but to persons of certain ranks in life, one must be civil, you know.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: I shall send to know if Lady Frankland be at home. If she is, I'll pay her a visit; perhaps Sir William may be there, and I may possibly discover something to corroborate our story. But that silly chit Emilia never leaves her, so that the woman wants opportunity, were she ever so well inclined—I wish that girl was any how out of the way.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: She'll marry Charles Frankland, and be a wretch.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: You have told me a most extraordinary story, James; are you sure your countryman's veracity may be depended upon.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Please your honour, I have known him from a child, and never had cause to doubt it—He is simply honest.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Then sure his master is an horrid villain! bid your friend attend me in my study—I must have all the particulars from himself. [Exit servant.] Can it be possible there lives a wretch so vile, to form a scheme for violating helpless innocence, and spoiling blooming beauty! my fair, my sen
sible Emilia, I will protect thee, at the hazard of my life; surely she holds a place within my breast, its feelings are too strong for friendship's power; her danger has awakened all my tenderness, en
deared her to my soul, and made me know esteem to be the surest base for love.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: The street before Lady FRANKLAND's house.

Enter a footman, with a card in his hand; as he is staring about for the house, Mr Frankland comes softly down the side of the stage, muffled in a cloak. Fontange opens the door, looks about, and lets him in.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: That was as nicely done now as if I had a hand in it, myself. High presto, pass and be gone—as the conjurer says. That must be the house, for I saw my lady's ugly Frenchwoman open the door—Aye, aye, I am right.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: So Nic.—How do'st do, my lad? Is your Lady at home?

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Why aye—I think so.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: There, carry that card to her then, from my lady madam Clarinda, and bring me an answer, straight.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Nic. has a rare place of it, surely—Such a fine handsome woman as his mistress, must have a deal of rich gallants come after her—And she is not cruel, I find.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: My lady will write an answer, directly, and you mun stay to carry it, for ise get going enough.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: You're a lucky rogue, Nic, to get into such a service; to have so beautiful a young lady your mistress—I warrant me you'll be for purchasing into the funds, by and by.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p:
Funds! I believe you'se making fun of me—Why mon, since those cursed sociations for drop
ping of vails, have been in fashion, a poor sarvant can scarce keep himself whole and clean. Funds quotha!

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p:
Why really, as you say, since the incroachment upon our perquisites, it is not worth any man of spirit's while to wear a livery, except where there is a little private business going forward—You under
stand me; and in that case, we must be touched handsomely, for hush-money, you know. I'll warrant now, you make above forty pounds a year of your lady.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p:
Not I, as I hope to be saved—She gives me but the bare ten guineas, and I have hardly any re
quisites at all; for my lady don't love play.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Don't she, really?
sp.stage: [Bell rings—Nic. goes out, and returns with a letter]

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: Here's my lady's answer

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Good by to you, friend Nic. Since you're so plaguy dry.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: That indeed, I am always—And should be glad to take a pot of beer with you, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Another time may serve, good Mr Sly-boots.
sp.stage:
SCENE draws, and discovers FONTANGE lead
ing in Mr. FKANKLAND.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p:
Oh, I am all in a fluster, I tremble from head to foot. If you do not succeed, that madame Clarin
da's serviteur discovery me—He saw me at de door—O, de bonté, monsieur, what vill become of me, if she be not very, very quiet?

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Why faith, mademoiselle, I find myself a little disconcerted too, at present, and have a foreboding sufficient to deter another man from the attempt, but I am determined to proceed, in spite of qualms, either of my conscience, or her virtue—This night puts an end to my life, or my misfortunes. I come prepared you see.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: O de bonne grace! you terrify me out of my life—Why, monsieur, if you should shoot a yourself, the king he get a your fortune—I never can recover my bond, against your heirs.

sp.speaker: Mr. FRANKLAND.
sp.p: You need not be in pain upon that account, mademoiselle, for if I should be taken off this moment, by an apoplexy, I should die my own executor.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Helas! den, I have venture my neck for noting, I have de great mind to go and discover de whole affair this very minute, since I find I am no to be paid.

sp.speaker: FRANKLAND.
sp.p: If you attempt to squeak, I shall silence you. Madame.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Pardonnez moi, monsieur, take away de pistol, and I vill no squeaka—But do, pray sign a de bond, if it be only for de satisfaction to my own conscience, that I did no commit a de sin, for noting.

sp.speaker: FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
There, mademoiselle, and may you be intitled to your reward, with all my heart. It is not wit
nessed, therefore not valid.

sp.speaker: FONTANGE.
sp.p: Je vous rend mille, grace, monsieur—The bell ring, get into that closet; de key is in de inside—Be sure you no stir, till all de house be in de bed.

sp.speaker: FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Doubt not my discretion.
sp.stage: [He goes into the closet, and exit mademoiselle.]

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: An apartment in Lady FANSHAW's house.
Lady FANSHAW and CLARINDA discovered at cards.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: You are repiqued, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: Well, that makes us even. I wish Thomas was returned.
sp.stage: Enter BETTY, and delivers a letter to CLARINDA.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: From Lady Frankland, ma'm,

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
To me! what can it mean? [Opens and reads] Lady Frankland's and Emilia's compliments to Clarinda, and request she will not give herself
the trouble of coming any more to Lady Frank
land's house, as they are under a necessity of de
clining her visits, for reasons not proper to be explained.—Forbid the house! this is astonishing!

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: It would almost tempt one to think they had a familiar, who could discover your heart to them.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: For that matter, I believe one of them is familiar enough—with the gentlemen, at least; if what Thomas says be true.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Why really, Betty, gentlemen are the most agreeable familiars a lady can have.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Very true, to be sure, my lady; but too much familiarity breeds content, as the proverb says; and I never should have thought of repeating what Thomas told me, the longest day I have to live, if it was not for their hypocrisy in refusing the visits of such a sweet virtuous lady as my mistress, that I have known, as it were, from a child. But some folks have fair faces, and foul hearts, in troth.—

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: They had better have shut other people's doors against me, than their own; for henceforth, where I enter, they never more shall be received—I'll blast that little prudish minx Emilia, too; I'll say any thing of them both that revenge can instigate.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Upon my verily, ma'm, I cannot bear to see you so instigationed by slights and malice, when if you knew but all, you need not be beholding to inven
tions, in the least, ma'm; for as sure as day, and as I hope to be saved, ma'm, Thomas saw a man
muffled up in a disguise, let in just n illegible w, to Lady Frankland's house, by her mademaselle there, who to be sure and sartin is like the rest of her country
women, no better than she should be.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: Ha, Clarinda! this is a lucky discovery for you.—I find her grave ladyship has not consined her studies intirely to romance, but has dipt a little into the more practical business of novel too, and seems to be a pretty apt scholar, for her time, truly.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p: This secret is worth a million—who could he be?

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: It must certainly be the sly Sir William.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
No matter who—She is now in my power, and I will use the advantage—This very instant I will write to Lord Frankland, he may command ad
mittance, though I am denied, for reasons not proper to be explained, and will, I hope, find reason to be convinced that her affected delicacy is as easily conquered, as the natural openness of my too generous heart.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I am sure it would be a burning sin, and shame too, not to detract, and ruinate such vild hypocrite creatures, for a couple of slippery heels, as they are.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p: I am of opinion, Clarinda, that your information will have but little weight with Lord Frankland, as you may be supposed to have some interest in the discovery.

sp.speaker: CLARINDA.
sp.p:
You are mistaken, madam, he has the quickest sense of honour, and will fly, either to convict or acquit her—Bid Thomas be in the way to carry my Letter. [Exit Betty. What a triumph will be mine! this night I shall ex
pose, and laugh to scorn the saint-like Lady Frank
land, tear off the veil she has so long assumed, and shew her genuine features to the world.

sp.speaker: Lady FANSHAW.
sp.p:
Well, come my dear, do give vent to your re
fentment—or it may hurt you mightily.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage:
Lady FRANKLAND's picture deprived of all its or
naments, the hair dishevelled, tears streaming from the eyes, and the hands in a supplicating posture.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I am uneasy, till I know from Emilia, whether my wife has broke off her intercouse with Clarinda.—Why should I doubt it? she never yet opposed my will, her temper's easy as her air; calm, placid, and serene, as that fair semblance.

Ha! what enchantment's this! that countenance, no longer placid and serene, speaks agonizing woe! the hair dishevelled too! the hands held up in sup
plication! can it be to me! tears streaming from the eyes, the precious drops, perhaps, of penitence and love! amazement all! Who waits?
Ambrose, look there! explain this wonder to my astonished sense, while I have reason left to comprehend you. How came that picture thus?

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: My dearest lord, upon my bended knees I beg forgiveness; but could you have seen with what an earnest fondness and desire she urged me to this deed, you would yourself have granted her request—How then could I refuse!

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Do not torture me! but say, with brevity, and truth, who urged you to this deed?

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: O! moderate the strong emotions of your mind, and I will tell you all. It was my lady Frankland, your lordship's fond, repentant, faithful wife—But if the crime be past forgiveness, O let your anger fall on me; even drive me from your sight, which of all punishments would be the saddest to me, but forgive my lady.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Rise, Ambrose, rise, and share your master's joy, which thus runs o'er. [Wiping his eyes, and gazing at the picture.] It must be so—It was her former, 'tis her present image. Quick let me fly then, to this fair trans
formed, kiss off the pearly drops from her pale cheek, and dry them with the warmest sighs of love; clasp those imploring hands, and press that heaving bosom to my heart.

sp.speaker: AMBROSE.
sp.p: May heaven be praised for this most blest event! I shall see my dearest lord and lady happy once more, and then I've lived enough.
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Lady FRANKLAND's dressing room, she sitting leaning on her arm, the ornaments of her head taken off.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
With what impatience have I told the minutes, since I deemed it possible Lord Frankland might have seen the picture! Ambrose, perhaps, de
ceived me. He may not look upon it, or if he should, how am I sure that he will turn his eyes on me? But should he even despise my sorrows, and leave me to my fate, I ought not to complain! But 'tis impossible—I know his generous heart will melt at my distress. At least, he sure will pity and forgive!
sp.stage: Enter Lord FRANKLAND, and stands at the side of the scene, gazing at her.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: My bounding heart springs from my breast, to meet her—How beautiful she looks! and Oh! how exquisite those charms, which even the veil of sorrow cannot shade!

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Heavens!
sp.stage: [Looking at him, and falling back in her chair.]

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Is then the dearest, fairest of her sex, again re
stored to the fond heart and arms, of her adoring husband!
sp.stage:
[Runs to catch her in his arms and em
brances her.]

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Oh! if not held unworthy of that blessing, her wishes are complete.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Unworthy, said you! you never were, nor could be so; through all the winding maze of gaiety and youth, my eyes have followed still their dar
ling object; nor has my heart one moment ceased to love, to pity, and esteem you. Had the charms of pleasure, or the snares of vice, infatuated your heart, that heart would ne'er have sighed to turn
again to me. When I was first flattered at re
ceiving the possession of it with that fair hand, I claimed it as an husband's right—I now accept it as a generous gift, and set the higher value on the prize.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Alas, my lord, your tenderness and generosity overpower me—They are indeed much more than I deserve, yet, though blushing for my follies, let me say no crime has rendered me unworthy of your goodness—My heart is free from stain, and hence
forth I may hope thy image there, shall shield it from all future weakness.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Can you suppose I doubt it, while with tran
sports such as those, I clasp it to my own.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
My dear Lady Erankland, joy, like mine, is not to be restrained by common forms—Lucy this moment told me she saw Lord Frankland come into your dressing room, and though perhaps, I inter
rupt your happiness, I must indulge my own, by wishing to you both, that true felicity which I well know you both deserve.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: The generous friend who has shared the sorrows of my heart, has a right surely to partake its joys; and if my present happiness could admit addition, it must be found in that which my Emilia feels.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I know of nought that could increase my bliss, but seeing you rejoice, Emilia.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p:
Madam, Sir William Belville is below, and begs to speak with you immediately; he says the cause of his intrusion at so late an hour, will be a sufficient apology for it. There is a servant of Mr Frank
land's, Patrick, madam, who says he has been at Lord Frankland's with a letter for him, but his lordship was not at home.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: They were mistaken, Lucy, for this is now my home.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: What shall I do, Lady Frankland?

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: See him, by all means, Emilia. There must be some uncommon cause for such an ill-timed visit.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Desire him to walk in here, Lucy, every mark of politeness, is due to his character.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: What business Mr Frankland's servant can have with Sir William, or with me, I can not imagine.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p: A little time will explain this mystery, Emilia.
sp.stage: Enter Sir WILLIAM, PATRICK, and LUCY.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
I am extremely happy at finding your Lordship here, as I am persuaded this meeting must render Lady Frankland and you so; and as the affair which brings me hither, concerns the honour of
your lordship's Family. For which reason I meant to have waited on you at your house.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Sir William I am very glad to see you, upon any occasion, but I think I have as little to fear, on the account you mention, as any man, for I happen not to be blest with any female relations, but those ladies who now stand before you.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
Then, my Lord, you may indeed boast your having nothing to be alarmed at from feminine connections; for if virtue and innocence were to be
come embodied, and chuse their forms, they would be those of Lady Frankland and Emilia—But your lordship has, I think, a male relation, counsellor Frankland.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Augh, that's my master, now, and faith myself is almost sorry I exposed him before such great company.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: What of him, Sir William? I look upon him as a very honest, sensible, and sober young man, rather too grave for one of his age.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Augh hone, how little he knows of him?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I fear then you are deceived, my lord—This honest simple fellow here, his own servant, this morning overheard a scheme laid between him and Fontange, Lady Frankland's woman, for no less than the absolute ruin of this lady.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: Heavens! how I tremble!

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I am unwilling to think so vilely of human na
ture, in any instance, and much more so of Charles Frankland, in particular, as to suppose this to be true. What proof can you produce, friend, that such a villainy was e'er intended?

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p:
Upon my safe conscience, my lord, my own two ears heard them talk about it, in my master's cham
bers; and that ugly jade, that madame Fontange, was to get a good thousand pounds for assisting him in carrying her off.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I cannot be persuaded that Charles is such a villain!

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p:
Why, my lord, if he is not in the house this very instant, why then Patrick's a lyar, and never believe him more, Augh-hone! myself is sorry enough for his doing such a bad thing, and it would break my heart to see him go to Tyburn for it, among a parcel of dirty, black-guard highway
men, that would lose their life for five or six guineas, and not among gentlemen, like himself, that would be hanged for killing their friend in a fair quarrel, or running handsomely away with their mistress. But upon my own soul, though, it would be a thousand pities to ruin that sweet creture, for all that.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
If Charles be found in the house, Emilia, I fear the rest of the story is then too true. Yet as the crime has not been perpetrated, I would wish to save him both from the shame, as well as the
punishment he deserves. I will go search, and bring him from his hold.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p:
I request your lordship will allow me, and this honest fellow, to attend you, if it be only to ap
prove our truth.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: By no means, Sir William, your honour has been proved sufficiently, in the detection. His servants honesty shall be rewarded.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Great luck to your lordship.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: How is it possible, Sir William, to repay this service?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I shall ever consider it as the greatest happiness of my life, that it has been in my power to render you any, madam; and if it might not appear to be presuming too much upon the present incident, I should intreat you to accept all the future services of my life. I rejoice to find your ladyship has led the way into the only path to real happiness.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
I have not the least doubt of your generosity, Sir William, and shall ever be ready, with true gra
titude, to own my obligations.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: If your ladyship thinks you have any, 'tis in your power to overpay them now, by joining me to request the fair Emilia to accept my hand and heart. Both your ladyship and I have seen the error of imagining they can be separated.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND,
sp.p:
I allow it, Sir William, and as I know no per
son so capable of rendering my Emilia happy, I en
treat—

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: My dear lady Frankland, I will not make a merit of granting that to your request, which I think Sir William's own deserts have a right to claim.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: The generous manner of conferring, would, if possible, double the obligation.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: I have secured the poor unhappy wretch to save him from himself.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Then it was true, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
Too true, Sir; I made his vile accomplice, trem
bling and scared, convey me to the place where he lay concealed; but when he saw me stand before him, guilt and confusion flashed into his face—He thought it was an apparition, and stiffened quite with horror. I closed upon him instantly, and seized the pistols which lay by his side. He then fell on his knees, confessed his crime, and begged that I would give him from my hand, that death which he deserved.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: I grieve to think, my lord, this happy hour should have been interrupted by such a sad event.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: 'Tis rather sure an addition to my bliss, that you are saved from misery, Emilia—But to Sir William Belville, your first and greatest thanks are due.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p: If he is not satisfied with my payments, my lord, he must e'en take out a statute of bankruptcy against me, for I have already surrendered to him every thing I was mistress of.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Then I give him joy, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: EMILIA.
sp.p:
As for you, honest Patrick, I think the least re
turn I can make you, for saving my life and ho¦nour, is to present you with the same sum that Fontange was to have had for destroying both.

sp.speaker: PATRICK.
sp.p: Heaven bless and prosper your ladyship, for that. Patrick will carry it into his own country, and that itself would be a help to poor Ireland, for every one has a pluck at it, and would be glad to take all they can get from it, and no body never gives it nothing at all.
sp.stage:
Enter NICODEMUS, with a letter to Lord FRANK
LAND.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p: One of your servants has just brought this from your lordship's house, he says the man who gave it him, bid him carry it where-ever you were, if he should not meet with your honour at home.

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p: Have I permission?
sp.stage: [They all bow, and he opens the letter; and looks at the bottom.
sp.p:
From Clarinda! [reads the letter] Malicious woman! Oh! let the venomed shaft with which she meant to wound my tenderest part, now lodge in her own breast. [Aside.] [Gives the letter to Lady Frankland.
You see, my dear, I had sufficient cause to warn you against this dangerous woman; and I am pleased to find that her resentment has arisen from your kind attention to my desire in forbidding her your house.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
This fortunate deliverance, with every other suc
cessful event of my future life, may add to my happiness, but cannot increase that love and grati
tude, with which my heart o'erflows to thee its generous protector, and its surest guide.

sp.speaker: NICODEMUS.
sp.p:
Please your ladyship, mademoiselle has got out of the window of the room where his lordship left her, thoa I'se have the key safe enough in my poc
ket—Shall I go after, and lug her back?

sp.speaker: Lord FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
No, let the wretch escape; the disappointment of her avarice, be the punishment of her crime; but henceforth I intreat my dearest wife will never employ foreigners again, while there are persons in our own country, both in trade and service, suf
ficient to supply our uses.

sp.speaker: Lady FRANKLAND.
sp.p:
In this, and every thing else, my pride and plea
sure shall be, to obey my dearest lord.
sp.l: Too plainly have I prov'd, that unconfin'd,
Our little skiff is toss'd by every wind,
On rocks and quicksands often is it cast,
And frequent sunk by cruel slander's blast;
But when our pilot at the helm appears,
With steady hand and compass when he steers.
In full security we sail with ease,
And fear nor driving winds, nor raging seas.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Clive, with an EPILOGUE in her Hand.

lg.l: OH! I am sick with laughing—almost dead!
Well! sure, of all the epilogues I ever read,
This is the dullest! ah! that head! that head!
Such flimsy, poor, quaint trash, was never penn'd!
And what's still worse, he stiles himself a friend.
I wish he'd be his own, and cease to write,
I vow the Christmas bell-man beats him quite.
Such stuff is only fit for Recitative,
Let's see—I'll try a stave or two—your leave—
"To you, ye brave, and also you, ye fair!
"Our female author does her fears declare—
"Invokes your pity—pleads her first offence,
"And that 'tis merit, ev'n to make pretence."
Ding! dong!
I'll write an air, myself, to't—then you'll roar
Bravo! bravissimo! divine! encore!
But hold—Piano, gentlefolks—For here
I'm running on, without all sense of fear—

What's this to'th' play? (puts up the paper) our au
thor, there she sits!
As I'm alive, she's going into fits!
Our female bard—the writer of this play—
Dear me! what is't that I was go'ng to say?
Lord, I'm so flounder'd! so confused!—No scheme
To bring me off!—I'll tell you an odd dream—
Not mine—t'was hers—So I'll just give you a hint,
And leave you to infer what meaning's in't.
Our Sappho took a nap—you'll say you know it;
Is that uncommon in a modern poet?
But let that pass—When borne on fancy's wing,
To the smoth brink of the Castalian spring,
She quaff'd so large a draught, it turned her brain
As mad—as some of you are with champaign—
Straight she began to rave 'bout inspiration!
Plot—diction—moral—sentiment—and passion.
Then scrambling up Parnassus' mount, she spied
The fiery Pegasus—and vow'd she'd ride.
Now I've been told, d'ye see, that this same steed,
Skittish, and fleet as your Newmarket breed,
Has dev'lish pranks—and none but men can ride him,
How aukard must our petticoats bestride him
'Faith, so it prov'd!
For as she, one foot in, and one foot out,
Was tittuping her hobby-horse about,
He gave a sudden frisk, reared up in th' air
And canted Sappho off—among ye there!
O dire prognostic of her present state!
I almost tremble to inquire her fate!
Explain this dream—O be our Art'midorus!
Expound by contraries, the doom before us!
Shall she remount? she'll bring him to his paces,
And shew you mettled sport, at future races?
But metaphor apart—This I dare say,
On the behalf of this probation play,
Y'are bound t'encourage it—I'll tell you why—
Wit, like provision, now is ris'n so high,
That illegible ome expedient we must fall upon,
To keep the market stock'd, or we're undone:
Now to abolish all monopoly,
And furnish out a choice, and full supply,
Take the advantage of a late decree,
Make't legal to import a quantity,
Of Irish wit—like butter—duty-free.
